subject: A Conversation With Cornwell
event: Bernard Cornwell has a new book coming out, which is great news if you're one of his fans, as I am. Or if you love great historical fiction. Or kickass stories, period. (And if you're a fantasy fan who has never read historical fiction... well, you need to broaden your horizons, and Cornwell is a terrific place to start. Especially if you like action. There's no one who writes better action scenes, in any genre). In honor of the occasion, our British publisher (HarperCollins) and Amazon arranged an email conversation/ interview between the two of us. Turns out Bernard has read my books as well, which pleased me no end). A short excerpt from our talk can be found on Amazon at: http://www.amazon.com/Death-Kings-Novel-Saxon-Tales/dp/0061969656/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1326120891&sr=1-1 Amazon only had room for a few questions, however. Actually, our talk went on considerably longer. The full interview will be going up soon on the HarperCollins website. I will be posting it on my own website as well. Will post a link here as soon as it's up. (Tuesday) OKAY! The complete conversation with Bernard Cornwell can now be found on my website, on the News page. Enjoy.

comments.article:
Thanks for the heads up ser! I haven't heard of him till now (maybe seen one or two of his books in passing). Another author I recommend to you, and to readers (which will help with the wait for ASOIF Book 6) is Jack Whyte. He re-imaged the story of Arthur, Merlyn & Camelot, in a Casino Royale, Batman Begins-esque way.

The series begins its roots with Roman occupied Britain. The first book is called The Skystone, and the final book is The Eagle.

I love his Arthurian series! I actually prefer that telling of it. It's actually where I got my screenname :)

I love Cornwell, but I’d hesitate to suggest he’s not to everyone’s taste. His story telling can be a little boy’s own adventure, especially in the early Sharpe books. But boy, can he write a good battle. At first the books can seem a bit black and white, the heroic Brits (and Irish) fighting the dastardly French, but in fact the biggest villains tend to be British officers. Give them a go, you’ll grow to love Sharpe. Either start with Sharpe’s Rifles, the initial book in the series or Sharpe’s Tiger, a prequel set in India, chronologically the first Sharpe story.

His later books, the Stories of King Arthur-Start with The Winter King or the ongoing Viking series-start with The Last Kingdom, might be the place to start for fans of GRRM.

He’s also written an American civil war series(The Starbuck Chronicles) and stand alone Novels, Stonehenge, Agincourt and his latest, an American revolution story- The Fort-told from both sides and far more balanced than anything Hollywood has portrayed.

On the same Amazon page you will see Conn Iggulden, most definitely give him a go. The new Cornwall I would say.

Bernard Cornwell is a must read for anyone interested in historical fiction. I've read all the Warlord Chronicles and Saxon series to date (recently finished Death Of Kings).

For people unfamiliar with the name, he is the creator of Richard Sharp (portrayed onscreen by Sean Bean).

Why no-one has ever optioned his Arthur or Saxon books for a series is beyond me. Come on HBO, the next big thing!

comments.article: I'll have to add Bernard Cornwell to my to read list. I'm currently knee deep in Bernard Knight's Crowner John mysteries. Not sure if you've ever read any Sharon Kay Penman but, she's probably my favorite historical fiction author and from her facebook page, I know she's read your books.
I'm a big fan of Cornwell, too, particularly his Sharpe books. He is an amazing historical fiction writer, almost unique in what he does, I think.

Bernard Cornwell describes real historical events with great realism and great imagination, then he combines that with action, battles, interesting characters and fast-paced stories. The results are novels that are great fun to read and really get your imagination going.

When I read his books, I always find myself doing research on the internet about his real historic characters and real historic events.
comments.subject: Bernard Conrwell is great

comments.article: Bernard Cornwell is one of the great historical fiction writers, and he doesn't just confine himself to the one time period, either. If anyone liked Cornwell I'd suggest trying out George MacDonald Fraser's magnificent Flashman series, something I believe GRRM is also quite fan of. Sadly GMF passed away a few years ago, but he left his readers with a wonderful legacy in the Flashman series.
Sharpie!

comments.article:
Could it get any better?

Cornwell's Warlord Chronicles are - to me - the hands-down best retelling of Arthur's story. His treatment of Lancelot and Guenivere are brilliant. His characters are so realistically flawed as well. As a person who, irl, has difficulty seeing people in anything other than black and white, this is immensely helpful to me on a personal level...
Thank you so much for a brilliant interview.
